question.content:
**Select the quadrant or axis where each ordered pair is located on a coordinate plane.**

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

hints.content:
Negative $x$-coordinates are left of the $y$-axis.

 

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/263b5c1199319bcf29bbcedb8e1b056d15147f98)

The $y$-coordinate is **not** $0$, so point $E$ **cannot** be located on the $x$-axis.  

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ef863db83561bcf42d097518d8b02542ee96cf40)
Point $E$ could be located in Quadrant II or Quadrant III.

question.content:
Point $E$ has a negative $x$-coordinate, and its $y$-coordinate is not $0$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $E$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Positive $y$-coordinates are above of the $x$-axis.

 

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/608329cdeb4f03d9584080c6cc391a40867671b6)
Point $E$ could be located in Quadrant I, Quadrant II or on the $y$-axis.

question.content:
Point $E$ has a positive $y$-coordinate.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $E$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Let's look at the signs of $x$- and $y$-coordinates in each quadrant.
 

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/206bb042ee3734fdbdbe94838e8f049c60f49da4)

The coordinates in quadrants II and IV have opposite signs.

Neither coordinate is $0$, so point $E$ **cannot** be located on an axis.  

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/639eaf6f03416e7e4c0bf369aaa5042a309a8b7d)
Point $E$ could be located in Quadrant II or Quadrant IV.

question.content:
Point $E\text{'s}$ $x$- and $y$-coordinates have different signs (one is positive and the other is negative).  Neither coordinate is $0$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $E$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
If a point's $y$-coordinate is $0$, then the point must be located on the $x$-axis.

 

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f81ec0e930630087cb62e1771d6578c78f88bc8a)

Point $E$ is located on the $x$-axis.

question.content:
Point $E\text{'s}$ $y$-coordinate is $0$, but its $x$-coordinate is not $0$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $E$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
$a$ is the $x$-coordinate and is positive.  

Positive $x$-coordinates are right of the $y$-axis.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/36957a9dbeb6971b6ebfe30d0ca4f35fe128f032)
Point $P$ could be located in Quadrant I, Quadrant IV, or on the $x$-axis.

question.content:
The ordered pair $(a, b)$ gives the location of point $P$ on the coordinate plane. The value of $a$ is positive.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $P$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Let's look at the signs of $x$- and $y$-coordinates in each quadrant.
 

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6d03cf5835d06f91ea20009e0a4b320374d6b646)

The coordinates in quadrants I and III have the same signs.

Neither coordinate is $0$, so point $P$ **cannot** be located on an axis.  

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/484995d062ef7fe64c834043bf4f3ba8646f3a99)
Point $P$ could be located in Quadrant I or Quadrant III.

question.content:
The ordered pair $(a, b)$ gives the location of point $P$ on the coordinate plane. The values of $a$ and $b$ have the same sign.  Neither $a$ nor $b$ is $0$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $P$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
$b$ is the $y$-coordinate and is negative.  

Negative $y$-coordinates are below the $x$-axis.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/50b7bdc74bf955c5c0decc3d714e050a67cccdb3)

$a$ is the $x$-coordinate and is **not** $0$.

So, point $P$ **cannot** be located on the $y$-axis.  

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/11eb5d6155da77f7dfb2ac015e5e1b6a03647520)
Point $P$ could be located in Quadrant III or Quadrant IV.

question.content:
The ordered pair $(a, b)$ gives the location of point $P$ on the coordinate plane. The value of $b$ is negative.  The value of  $a$ is *not* $0$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $P$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
$a$ is the $x$-coordinate.  

If a point's $x$-coordinate is $0$, then the point must be located on the $y$-axis.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/68124d507b28793600b9ded6fdfd86878e369c07)

Point $P$ is located on the $y$-axis.

question.content:
The ordered pair $(a, b)$ gives the location of point $P$ on the coordinate plane. The value of $a$ is $0$, but $b$ is not zero.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b9646357f8af86eb1ec25bc0baf6620465223ff)

**Where could point $P$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
